guide.introduction_rendered:
In this project we demonstrate how to make a bridge rectifier which transforms AC voltage to DC voltage. This project can be created on a breadboard or a PCB. Before we begin, make sure you have acquired all of the parts to the specifications listed above. Let's begin!

Relevant parts
  • 470uf Capacitors
  • 14awg-20awg hook-up wire
  • Header Pins
  • Bridge rectifier
Tools
  • Needle Nose Pliers
  • Small Breadboard
  • Solder Iron w/ Solder
  • Wire cutters

lines.text: Capacitor C1 AND C2 470uF help smooth the output of the rectifier. The Caps are marked with a (-) on one of the leads, you should connect these to ground (-), and the other lead to the positive output, marked + on the rectifier.
lines.text_raw: Capacitor C1 AND C2 470uF help smooth the output of the rectifier. The Caps are marked with a (-) on one of the leads, you should connect these to ground (-), and the other lead to the positive output, marked + on the rectifier.

lines.text: This is the schematic for the bridge rectifier.  Its purpose is to convert or "rectify" the incoming AC  voltage into a DC voltage.
lines.text_raw: This is the schematic for the bridge rectifier.  Its purpose is to convert or "rectify" the incoming AC  voltage into a DC voltage.

lines.text: You are going to make this from 4 each 1N4007 diodes. Start by twisting together the cathodes of 2 diodes (the end marked with a line). Take the remaining 2 diodes and twist together their anodes (the end without a line :).
lines.text_raw: You are going to make this from 4 each 1N4007 diodes. Start by twisting together the cathodes of 2 diodes (the end marked with a line). Take the remaining 2 diodes and twist together their anodes (the end without a line :).

lines.text: Now take the first set of diodes - the ones with their cathodes twisted together, and twist one of the anodes to a loose end (the anode) of the other pair.

lines.text: Twist the two remaining ends together.  Your bridge rectifier should look like the photo. If it does, solder the places where you twisted the diodes together.
